citation.article-title: Three new species of the genus Actinobispora of the family Pseudonocardiaceae, Actinobispora alaniniphila sp. nov., Actinobispora aurantiaca sp. nov. and Actinobispora xinjiangensis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Actinobispora aurantiaca sp. nov.
Actinobispora aurantiaca (au .ran. ti'a .ca. M . L. fem.adj. aurantiaca orange-coloured)
Gram-positive, non-acid-fast and aerobic.
The vegetative and aerial hyphae are branched but not fragmented.
Spores are borne in longitudinal pairs on vegetative hyphae and in longitudinal pairs or singly on aerial hyphae and are not motile.
Vegetative hyphae are orange to orange-yellow.
Aerial mycelium is sparse and pink-white.
Melanin and diffusible pigment which is brilliant yellow on oatmeal agar are produced.
Cells utilize cellobiose, D-fructose, raffinose, L-rhamnose, alanine, histidine and proline, but not adonitol, inulin, mannitol, xylose or inositol.
Acid is not produced from these carbon sources.
Milk is not coagulated and peptonized.
Gelatin is liquefied.
Urea is degraded.
Pectinase is produced.
Nitrate is not reduced.
The strain has weak antimicrobial activity against Bacillus subtilis.
No growth at 45 Â°C.
The cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic as the diamino acid.
The whole-cell hydrolysate contains galactose and arabinose.
The strain lacks mycolic acid but contains PC, PE, GluNu and PG.
The major menaquines are MK-9(H2), MK- 7(H2) and MK-7(H4).
The type strain is strain Y-14860T (=CCTCC AA97002T), which was isolated from a soil sample collected at Jianchuan, Yunnan, China.
